One of the fundamental flaws considered to exist with Newtonian gravity (itself, unlike most Newtonian mechanics/theories, quite an underdeveloped theory; as proven by how it failed to explain the precession of Mercury) is that it was a Force that pulled.

Aside from its failure to accurately explain the precession of Mercury (which frustrated Newton and others); the limitations and/or lack of maturity associated with Newton's gravitational theory were also conspicuous by the fact that most forces - especially at the time Einstein developed his relativistic and/or counter-theories - were considered to "push"; a point that not only captured Einstein's attention but also was said to motivate him with the development of his general theory of relativity.

Relativity (which does explain the precession of Mercury and therefore trumps Newton in that and other respects) tells us that gravity is not a Force at all, but, instead, it is a geometric property of space and time; or "spacetime".

Therefore - and particularly considering the compare's (Derek) attention to detail not only in the field of science (which I commend) but also his other videos on relativity - perhaps, in the very least, he should consider discussing gravity as a Force that pushes; if in fact he must discuss it as a Force at all.

It's Newton's third law

Centrifugal force is an outward 'force' that is observed from within rotating frames.  It is the result of inertia, and it COUNTERS the force due to gravity, so you have it backward.  At the equator (where the rotation and therefore centrifugal force are the greatest), you feel lighter.  At the poles, where there is virtually no rotation, you feel the heaviest.

Note :  The Earth also bulges at the equator (due to the same centrifugal force) so the gravitaional force is also weaker.

What's a centrifugal force? I think you mean the centripetal force at the poles is smaller than at the equator thus contributing less to your weight. You "feel" heavier at the equator than at the north or south pole.

We have yet to even fully understand gravity. Newton admitted it.  Einstein admitted it. Newton provided a way to accurate calculate the 'force' of gravity, and that is still perfectly valid in most applications today. If you wish to only count Einstein's view of gravity as valid, then to be technical, gravity is neither a push nor a pull.  In relativistic physics, gravity is not a force at all, so to call it a 'pull' is just as wrong as calling it a 'push'. In relativity, it is inertial motion.

"they don't even teach gravity properly in most schools." - Yes and no.  Learning gravity from a Newtonian standpoint is not 'wrong'.  It is just a first step.  You're going to have to learn Newtonian physics before you learn modern physics and part of that is Newtonian gravity.  You can't just teach modern physics, specifically relativistic gravity, to students who have not yet learned Newtonian physics.  They would be completely lost.  To be continued...
nice editing at 1:02

It depends on how you are looking at it.  In Newtonian physics, gravity is a force between objects with mass.  In this light, the gravity of the Earth PULLS you.  In relativistic physics, gravity is caused by a curvature of space.  In this light, you can make the argument that it is a PUSH.  Either way, does it really matter?  This should NOT bug you.  When it comes down to it, gravity is BOTH a push and a pull depending on what frame you are in.  It just doesn't matter to physicists.

If the elevator is accelerating at -2m/s² (going down) then the normal force is only 468 N (588-120).  Notice how you feel heavier when an elevator starts upward, and lighter when it starts downward?  You are not gaining and losing weight.  You are just feeling the varying normal force acting on you to keep you from falling through the elevator floor.

NOTE :  An elevator does NOT accelerate all the way up or all the way down.  Just initially when it goes from 0 to full speed.

When I said, "then the normal force will be your weight PLUS the acceleration of the elevator", I meant your weight plus the force CAUSING the acceleration.  For example, If your mass is 60 kg, then your weight is 588 Newtons(N) (W=(60kg)(9.8m/s²).  When standing on the Earth, the normal force is also 588 N.  If you are in an elevator that is accelerating upward at 2 m/s², then the force on you causing this acceleration is 120 N ((60kg)(2m/s²)).  The normal force is 708 N. (588+120)

When you are standing on firm AND level ground (the Earth), the normal force is equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to your weight.  If the surface you are standing on is being accelerated (as in an accelerating elevator), then the normal force will be your weight PLUS the acceleration of the elevator.  If you are standing on an incline, the normal force is acting perpendicular to the surface, and does not equal weight since friction is helping counter your weight.

According to general relativity, gravity is not a force. It's the name we've given to the effect that massive objects cause to the spacetime around it, and therefore to other objects in the surrounding spacetime.

I often find that you shouldn't think of it as action/reaction. Because the fact of the matter is that everything is acting from some frame of reference (only exception I can think of is at 0K). You can think of the normal force being a reaction to the gravitational pull on your body forcing you to the ground or instead your body in the way of the Earth's movement through space. Same thing really (though there are complexities). The best way to look at forces is as INTER-actions between objects.

(continued from previous post)...where gravity confuses me is this:  Since we know gravity is a continual force of attraction -- if we jump again, we'll fall back down again, over and over -- how can we reconcile this with the fact that with matter, force = mass x acceleration?  In a spacial sense, we're not longer accelerating (we're not falling once we hit the ground).  So where has the acceleration of gravity gone to?  Is it decelerating the acceleration caused by the normal force?  Any help?

I prefer to think of it as we are bodies accelerating toward the center of the earth (since the earth has so much more inertia).  When we contact a surface (say we just jumped up and fell back down to the ground) there is an a momentum interaction. If the surface we land on is softer or more elastic, our joints don't need to bend as much to prevent us from getting injured or bouncing.  Yet, gravity doesn't stop, we're still attracted to the center of the earth and ground keeps pushing back....

Yep, Newton's Second law. An object at rest will remain at rest until acted upon by an outside force. Put another way: A force causes an object at rest to accelerate. The specific mechanics of how the acceleration happens is different for each of the fundamental forces, but the only definition for a force is something which causes acceleration.

I have to say I'm disappointed in this as there are, in fact, four forces operating on any body made of atoms, that being Gravitational, Electromagnetic, Strong and Weak Forces and all others are just consequences of that. In the case of the you and the Earth, your body is trying to make a smaller circular path due to being much lighter, but the reaction (normal) force from the Earth is keeping the resultant force such that you travel the same path as the outside of the Earth.

Technically that force doesn't exist, it's only the differing circular paths of you and the Earth due to the different masses. Imagine when you're in a car, turning a corner. You are being forced outwards right? Well that's just the car travelling in a different path to you, because it has the force from its wheels making it turn, whereas the only thing keeping you in your seat is friction, which is much less, so when turning a tight corner your circular path is much larger than the car's.

@bramshih This is a good question. The answer is Newton's Third Law is never violated. If you are standing still the normal force must be equal to your weight.
